messages.content: Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

World War I (WWI), also known as the First World War, was a global conflict fought between two coalitions, the Allied Powers and the Central Powers. Fighting took place throughout Europe, the Middle East, Africa, the Pacific, and parts of Asia. One of the deadliest wars in history, it resulted in an estimated 9 million soldiers dead and 23 million wounded, plus another 5 million civilian deaths from various causes. Millions more died as a result of genocide, and the war was a major factor in the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic. The first decade of the 20th century saw increasing diplomatic tension between the European great powers. This reached a breaking point on 28 June 1914, when a Bosnian Serb named Gavrilo Princip assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand, heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne. Austria-Hungary held Serbia responsible, and declared war on 28 July. Russia came to Serbia's defence, and by 4 August, Germany, France, and Britain were drawn into the war, with the Ottoman Empire joining in November of that same year. Germany's strategy in 1914 was to first defeat France, then transfer forces to the Russian front. However, this failed, and by the end of 1914, the Western Front consisted of a continuous line of trenches stretching from the English Channel to Switzerland. The Eastern Front was more dynamic, but neither side could gain a decisive advantage, despite costly offensives. As the war expanded to more fronts, Bulgaria, Romania, Greece, Italy and others joined in from 1915 onward. In early 1917, the United States entered the war on the side of the Allies, and later the same year, the Bolsheviks seized power in the Russian October Revolution, making peace with the Central Powers in early 1918. Germany launched an offensive in the west in March 1918, and despite initial success, it left the German Army exhausted and demoralised. A successful Allied counter-offensive later that year caused a collapse of the German frontline. By the end of 1918, Bulgaria, the Ottoman Empire and Austria-Hungary agreed to armistices with the Allies, leaving Germany isolated. Facing revolution at home and with his army on the verge of mutiny, Kaiser Wilhelm II abdicated on 9 November.

{"flashcards": [{ "term": "World War I", "definition": "Also known as the First World War, it was a global conflict fought between two coalitions, the Allied Powers and the Central Powers." }, { "term": "Allied Powers", "definition": "A coalition of countries including Britain, France, Russia, and later the United States, that fought against the Central Powers in World War I." }, { "term": "Central Powers", "definition": "A coalition of countries including Germany, Austria-Hungary, and the Ottoman Empire, that fought against the Allied Powers in World War I." }, { "term": "Archduke Franz Ferdinand", "definition": "Heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, whose assassination by Gavrilo Princip in 1914 triggered the start of World War I." }, { "term": "Trenches", "definition": "Long, narrow ditches dug into the ground, used for protection and to defend positions during World War I." }, { "term": "Western Front", "definition": "The line of trenches stretching from the English Channel to Switzerland where the majority of fighting took place between the Allied and Central Powers in World War I." }, { "term": "Eastern Front", "definition": "The region where the fighting between the Allied and Central Powers took place in Eastern Europe and Russia during World War I." }, { "term": "United States", "definition": "A country that entered World War I on the side of the Allies in 1917." }, { "term": "Russian October Revolution", "definition": "The revolution in Russia in 1917 that led to the Bolsheviks seizing power and making peace with the Central Powers in World War I." }, { "term": "Armistice", "definition": "A formal agreement to stop fighting, often used to refer to the agreements that ended World War I." }, { "term": "Kaiser Wilhelm II", "definition": "The German emperor who abdicated on 9 November 1918, marking the end of World War I for Germany." }]}
Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

An array is a number of elements in a specific order, typically all of the same type (depending on the language, individual elements may either all be forced to be the same type, or may be of almost any type). Elements are accessed using an integer index to specify which element is required. Typical implementations allocate contiguous memory words for the elements of arrays (but this is not always a necessity). Arrays may be fixed-length or resizable. A linked list (also just called list) is a linear collection of data elements of any type, called nodes, where each node has itself a value, and points to the next node in the linked list. The principal advantage of a linked list over an array is that values can always be efficiently inserted and removed without relocating the rest of the list. Certain other operations, such as random access to a certain element, are however slower on lists than on arrays. A record (also called tuple or struct) is an aggregate data structure. A record is a value that contains other values, typically in fixed number and sequence and typically indexed by names. The elements of records are usually called fields or members. In the context of object-oriented programming, records are known as plain old data structures to distinguish them from objects.[11] Hash tables, also known as hash maps, are data structures that provide fast retrieval of values based on keys. They use a hashing function to map keys to indexes in an array, allowing for constant-time access in the average case. Hash tables are commonly used in dictionaries, caches, and database indexing. However, hash collisions can occur, which can impact their performance. Techniques like chaining and open addressing are employed to handle collisions.

{"flashcards": [{ "term": "Array", "definition": "A number of elements in a specific order, typically all of the same type. Elements are accessed using an integer index." }, { "term": "Linked List", "definition": "A linear collection of data elements, where each node has a value and points to the next node in the list." }, { "term": "Record", "definition": "An aggregate data structure that contains other values, typically in fixed number and sequence." }, { "term": "Hash Table", "definition": "Data structures that provide fast retrieval of values based on keys using a hashing function." }]}
Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

The chicken (Gallus domesticus) is a domesticated species that arose from the red junglefowl, originally from Southeast Asia. They have also partially hybridized with other wild species of junglefowl (the grey junglefowl, Ceylon junglefowl, and green junglefowl).[1] Rooster and cock are terms for adult male birds, and a younger male may be called a cockerel. A male that has been castrated is a capon. An adult female bird is called a hen, and a sexually immature female is called a pullet. Humans keep chickens primarily as a source of food (consuming both their meat and eggs) or as pets. Traditionally, they were also bred for cockfighting, which is still practiced in some places. Chickens domesticated for meat are broilers, and for eggs, they are layers. Chickens are one of the most common and widespread domestic animals, with a total population of 23.7 billion as of 2018,[2] up from more than 19 billion in 2011. There are more chickens in the world than any other bird. There are numerous cultural references to chickens—in myth, folklore, and religion, as well as in language and literature. Genetic studies have pointed to multiple maternal origin theories within South Asia, Southeast Asia, and East Asia,[3] but the clade found in the Americas, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa originated from the Indian subcontinent. From ancient India, the chicken spread to the Eastern Mediterranean. They appear in ancient Egypt in the mid-15th century BC, with the 'bird that gives birth every day' having come from the land between Syria and Shinar, Babylonia, according to the annals of Thutmose III.[4][5][6] They are known in ancient Greece from the 5th century BC.

{"flashcards": [{"term": "Chicken", "definition": "The domesticated species that arose from the red junglefowl."}, {"term": "Rooster", "definition": "An adult male chicken."}, {"term": "Cock", "definition": "An adult male chicken."}, {"term": "Cockerel", "definition": "A younger male chicken."}, {"term": "Capon", "definition": "A castrated male chicken."}, {"term": "Hen", "definition": "An adult female chicken."}, {"term": "Pullet", "definition": "A sexually immature female chicken."}, {"term": "Broilers", "definition": "Chickens domesticated for meat."}, {"term": "Layers", "definition": "Chickens domesticated for egg production."}, {"term": "Chicken Population", "definition": "The total population of chickens was 23.7 billion as of 2018."}, {"term": "Chicken Origins", "definition": "Genetic studies point to multiple maternal origin theories within South Asia, Southeast Asia, and East Asia."}, {"term": "Chicken Spread", "definition": "Chickens spread from ancient India to the Eastern Mediterranean."}, {"term": "Ancient References", "definition": "Chickens are referenced in ancient Egypt and ancient Greece."}]}
Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

Othello begins on a street in Venice, in the midst of an argument between Roderigo and Iago. The rich Roderigo has been paying Iago to help him win Desdemona's hand in marriage, but he has seen no progress, and he has just learned that Desdemona has married Othello, a general whom Iago serves as ensign. Iago reassures Roderigo that he hates Othello. Chief among Iago’s reasons for this hatred is Othello’s recent promotion of Michael Cassio to the post of lieutenant. In spite of Iago’s service in battle and the recommendation of three “great ones” of the city, Othello chose to give the position to a man with no experience leading men in battle. As he waits for an opportunity to further his own self-interest, Iago only pretends to serve Othello. Iago advises Roderigo to spoil some of Othello’s pleasure in his marriage by rousing Desdemona’s family against the general. The two men come to the street outside the house of Desdemona’s father, Brabantio, and cry out that he has been robbed by “thieves.” Brabantio, who is a Venetian senator, comes to the window. At first, he doesn’t believe what he hears, because he has told Roderigo to stay away from his daughter before and thinks Roderigo is merely scheming once again in order to see Desdemona. Iago speaks in inflammatory terms, vulgarly telling the senator that his daughter and Othello are having sex by saying that they are “making the beast with two backs” (I.i.118). Brabanzio begins to take what he hears seriously and decides to search for his daughter. Seeing the success of his plan, Iago leaves Roderigo alone and goes to attend on Othello. Like Brabanzio, Othello has no idea of Iago’s role in Roderigo’s accusations. As Iago departs, Brabanzio comes out of his house, furious that his daughter has left him. Declaring that his daughter has been stolen from him by magic “charms,” Brabanzio and his men follow Roderigo to Othello.

{"flashcards": [{"term": "Who is Roderigo?", "definition": "A wealthy man who is in love with Desdemona and is manipulated by Iago to pursue her."}, {"term": "Who is Iago?", "definition": "The main antagonist, who manipulates Roderigo and harbors a deep hatred for Othello."}, {"term": "Who is Desdemona?", "definition": "The woman Roderigo and Othello are both interested in, whom Othello marries."}, {"term": "Michael Cassio", "definition": "A man promoted to the post of lieutenant by Othello, which fuels Iago's hatred."}, {"term": "Brabantio", "definition": "Desdemona's father and a Venetian senator."}, {"term": "What narrative purpose did the Promotion of Cassio serve?", "definition": "A source of Iago's resentment, as Othello promoted Cassio to a position Iago wanted."}, {"term": "What were the accusations against Othello?", "definition": "Roderigo and Iago accuse Othello of robbing Brabantio's daughter and having an affair with her."}, {"term": "Iago's manipulation", "definition": "Iago manipulates Roderigo to create problems for Othello and Desdemona."}, {"term": "Brabantio's reaction", "definition": "Brabantio becomes enraged and believes his daughter was stolen by Othello through magic charms."}]}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "What is a Ranger?", "definition": "A character class in tabletop role-playing games that specializes in wilderness survival and combat."}, {"term": "What are Hit Points?", "definition": "A measure of a character's health and durability in the game, determined by hit dice and Constitution modifier. (10 + Constitution modifier at first level)"}, {"term": "What are a Ranger’s Hit Dice?", "definition": "The type of dice used to determine hit points for a ranger (1d10 per ranger level)."}, {"term": "What are Proficiencies?", "definition": "Skills and abilities that rangers are trained in, including armor, weapons, saving throws, and skills."}, {"term": "What are a Ranger’s Armor Proficiencies?", "definition": "Rangers are proficient in light armor, medium armor, and shields."}, {"term": "What are a Ranger’s Weapon Proficiencies?", "definition": "Rangers are proficient in simple weapons and martial weapons."}, {"term": "What are the Ranger’s Saving Throws Proficiencies?", "definition": "Rangers have proficiency in saving throws for Strength and Dexterity."}, {"term": "What can be a Ranger’s Skills Proficiencies?", "definition": "Rangers can choose three skills from a list including Animal Handling, Athletics, Insight, Investigation, Nature, Perception, Stealth, and Survival."}]}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "What is OpenGL?", "definition": "OpenGL is a specification for a graphics API (Application Programming Interface) that provides functions for manipulating graphics and images."}, {"term": "Who is the Khronos Group?", "definition": "The organization responsible for developing and maintaining the OpenGL specification."}, {"term": "OpenGL Implementation", "definition": "The actual software libraries and drivers developed by graphics card manufacturers or other entities to implement the OpenGL specification on specific hardware."}, {"term": "What are Graphics Card Manufacturers?", "definition": "Companies that produce graphics cards and develop OpenGL implementations for their hardware."}, {"term": "What can Updating Video Card Drivers do?", "definition": "A recommended action to fix issues with OpenGL implementations, as newer drivers often include bug fixes and support for the latest OpenGL versions."}, {"term": "What is an OpenGL Specification?", "definition": "A document specifying how OpenGL functions should behave and the results they should produce, without providing implementation details."}]}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "What is Accounting?", "definition": "The practice of recording, organizing, and reporting financial information for businesses and individuals."}, {"term": "What are Financial Records?", "definition": "Documents that track financial transactions and activities within a business or organization."}, {"term": "Who are Regulators?", "definition": "Government or industry authorities responsible for overseeing and enforcing financial rules and regulations."}, {"term": "What are Cash Flows?", "definition": "The movement of money in and out of a business, which accountants analyze and report."}, {"term": "What is Financial Performance?", "definition": "Refers to how well a business is doing financially, often assessed through income statements and other financial reports."}, {"term": "What are an Accountant's Daily Tasks?", "definition": "The responsibilities of accountants, including overseeing financial records, creating budgets, preparing financial documents, attending meetings, collecting and reviewing data, ensuring compliance with laws, and forecasting."}, {"term": "What are Audits?", "definition": "Examinations of financial records to ensure accuracy and compliance with regulations."}, {"term": "Forecasting and Risk Assessment", "definition": "Evaluating future financial trends and potential risks to help businesses make informed decisions."}]}
Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

Neurons + Refractory Period:
Neurons are important cells in the nervous system that are responsible for sending messages via electrical impulses and chemical signals around the brain and other parts of the nervous system. A neuron is composed of three sections: the soma (cell body), which contains the nucleus of the cell, dendrites that receive chemical messengers from other neurons, and an axon that sends signals to other cells via electrical and chemical (neurotransmitter) signals. Neurons send signals to other cells with chemical neurotransmitters. However, because neurons can be up to three feet long, they have a unique way of sending the signal from one end of the axon to the other via electrical signals called action potentials. When a neuron receives a neurotransmitter signal from another cell, the axon fires an action potential down to the axon terminal (end of the axon), where the electrical signal is converted back into a chemical neurotransmitter and is able to signal neighboring cells.

Since action potentials take about one millisecond to travel the length of the axon, it could be expected that neurons fire constantly, but this is not the case. Each time after an action potential is fired, the neuron undergoes refractory periods. What is refractory period? During refractory period, neurons reset and cover after firing an action potential. There are two types of refractory periods, absolute and relative. The absolute refractory period occurs immediately after an action potential is fired and it is not possible for another action potential to be produced. A relative refractory period takes place after the absolute refractory period. During relative refractory period, another action potential could possibly occur, but only if a neuron receives a much stronger stimulus than the previous action potential.

{"flashcards": [{"term": "What are Neurons?", "definition": "Cells in the nervous system responsible for transmitting messages through electrical impulses and chemical signals."}, {"term": "What is a Soma (Cell Body)?", "definition": "The central part of a neuron containing the cell's nucleus."}, {"term": "What are Dendrites?", "definition": "Branch-like structures that receive chemical messages from other neurons."}, {"term": "What is an Axon?", "definition": "A long projection that transmits signals to other cells through electrical and chemical neurotransmitter signals."}, {"term": "Define Neurotransmitters?", "definition": "Chemical messengers used by neurons to transmit signals to other cells."}, {"term": "What are Action Potentials?", "definition": "Electrical signals that travel down the axon of a neuron, allowing it to transmit signals to other cells."}, {"term": "Axon Terminal", "definition": "The end of the axon where electrical signals are converted back into chemical neurotransmitters to signal neighboring cells."}, {"term": "What is a Refractory Period?", "definition": "A period during which a neuron resets and recovers after firing an action potential."}, {"term": "What is an Absolute Refractory Period?", "definition": "An immediate period following an action potential during which it is impossible for another action potential to be produced."}, {"term": "What is a Relative Refractory Period?", "definition": "A period following the absolute refractory period during which another action potential could occur if the neuron receives a stronger stimulus than the previous one."}]}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "Link between Vaccines and Autism", "definition": "The idea that vaccines may cause Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), which has been scientifically disproven."}, {"term": "ASD (Autism Spectrum Disorder)", "definition": "A developmental disorder characterized by challenges in social interaction and communication, with a range of symptoms and severity."}, {"term": "National Academy of Medicine", "definition": "An institution that reviewed the safety of vaccines and concluded that, with rare exceptions, vaccines are very safe."}, {"term": "What is the CDC?", "definition": "A U.S. government agency, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, that conducted studies confirming that vaccines do not cause ASD."}, {"term": "What are Antigens?", "definition": "Substances in vaccines that stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies and fight diseases."}, {"term": "What is Thimerosal?", "definition": "A mercury-based preservative used in vaccines to prevent contamination; research has shown it does not cause ASD."}, {"term": "What is the IOM?", "definition": "A scientific institution, the Institute of Medicine, that reviewed and concluded that there is no causal relationship between thimerosal-containing vaccines and autism."}, {"term": "What is an MMR Vaccine?", "definition": "Measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine; studies have found no link between the MMR vaccine and ASD in children."}]}
Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

Adults + Napping:
If you're sleep deprived or just looking for a way to relax, you might be thinking about taking a nap. Napping at the wrong time of day or for too long can backfire, though. Understand how to get the most out of a nap.
What are the benefits of napping?
Napping offers various benefits for healthy adults, including:
	Relaxation
	Reduced fatigue
	Increased alertness
	Improved mood
	Improved performance, including quicker reaction time and better memory

What are the drawbacks to napping?
Napping isn't for everyone. Some people simply can't sleep during the day or have trouble sleeping in places other than their own beds, which napping sometimes requires.
Napping can also have negative effects, such as:
	Sleep inertia. You might feel groggy and disoriented after waking up from a nap.
	Nighttime sleep problems. Short naps generally don't affect nighttime sleep quality for most people. But if you experience insomnia or poor sleep quality at night, napping might worsen these problems. Long or frequent naps might interfere with nighttime sleep.

When should I consider a nap?
You might consider making time for a nap if you:
	Experience new fatigue or unexpected sleepiness
	Are about to experience sleep loss — for example, due to a long work shift
	Want to make planned naps part of your daily routine

Flashcards:
{"term": "What are some Benefits of Napping?", "definition": "The advantages of taking a nap for healthy adults, including relaxation, reduced fatigue, increased alertness, improved mood, and enhanced performance in terms of reaction time and memory."}
{"term": "What are some Drawbacks of Napping?", "definition": "Potential negative effects of napping, such as sleep inertia (grogginess after waking up) and the possibility of worsening nighttime sleep problems."}
{"term": "Define Sleep Inertia", "definition": "The groggy and disoriented feeling that can occur after waking up from a nap or sleep."}
{"term": "What are Nighttime Sleep Problems", "definition": "Issues related to sleep quality at night, which can be exacerbated by napping, particularly if the naps are long or frequent."}
{"term": "When to Consider a Nap?", "definition": "When it's appropriate to take a nap, including if you're experiencing fatigue or unexpected sleepiness, anticipate sleep loss (e.g., due to work shifts), or want to incorporate planned naps into your daily routine."}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "What are some Benefits of Napping?", "definition": "The advantages of taking a nap for healthy adults, including relaxation, reduced fatigue, increased alertness, improved mood, and enhanced performance in terms of reaction time and memory."}, {"term": "What are some Drawbacks of Napping?", "definition": "Potential negative effects of napping, such as sleep inertia (grogginess after waking up) and the possibility of worsening nighttime sleep problems."}, {"term": "Define Sleep Inertia", "definition": "The groggy and disoriented feeling that can occur after waking up from a nap or sleep."}, {"term": "What are Nighttime Sleep Problems", "definition": "Issues related to sleep quality at night, which can be exacerbated by napping, particularly if the naps are long or frequent."}, {"term": "When to Consider a Nap?", "definition": "When it's appropriate to take a nap, including if you're experiencing fatigue or unexpected sleepiness, anticipate sleep loss (e.g., due to work shifts), or want to incorporate planned naps into your daily routine."}]}

The Dos of a professional Work Email:
The Dos

Do: Use proper salutation
Opening an email with “hi” or “hey” might be alright for colleagues you’re friendly with, but for new contacts, Schweitzer advised beginning your email with a proper, respectful salutation, such as “good morning,” “good afternoon,” “good evening” or “hello.”
“‘Good day’ or ‘greetings’ are other phrases used frequently in the international arena,” she added.

Do: Proofread
Before you send, make sure to carefully proofread and edit your email. You should look for misspellings, homonyms, grammar and punctuation errors, Smith said. Careless email mistakes will only make you look bad to your recipients.

“These errors look unprofessional and reduce the likelihood that the email will be taken seriously,” added Schweitzer. “Email software comes with many professional tools such as spell check. Use them.”

Do: Stay concise
It’s always best to keep your emails short and sweet. Emails are not meant to be as brief as text messages, Smith said, but they are meant to be a form of quick communication. If your email is too wordy, try editing it down to make it more concise.
“Recipients will only read the first line or two before deciding whether to keep or delete [an email],” Smith said. “Be sure you are saying what you need to say sufficiently.”

Do: Keep Calm
Never send any email while you are angry or otherwise emotional, Smith advised. Instead, try to calm down and then speak to the person you need to address face-to-face or over the phone if an in-person meeting is not possible. Doing so could help you avoid an unnecessary altercation, Smith said.

Flashcards:
{"term": "Dos in Email Etiquette", "definition": "Positive practices to follow when composing and sending emails."}
{"term": "What is a Proper Salutation?", "definition": "Using respectful and appropriate greetings like 'good morning,' 'good afternoon,' or 'hello' when addressing recipients, particularly in professional or new contact settings."}
{"term": "What is Proofreading?", "definition": "Thoroughly reviewing and editing your email for errors, including misspellings, grammar, and punctuation mistakes."}
{"term": "Why be Concise?", "definition": "Keeping emails short and to the point for efficient and effective communication, while avoiding excessive wordiness."}
{"term": "What is meant by Keeping Calm?", "definition": "Avoid sending emails in anger or when emotionally charged; instead, address the issue in person or over the phone to prevent unnecessary conflicts."}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "Dos in Email Etiquette", "definition": "Positive practices to follow when composing and sending emails."}, {"term": "What is a Proper Salutation?", "definition": "Using respectful and appropriate greetings like 'good morning,' 'good afternoon,' or 'hello' when addressing recipients, particularly in professional or new contact settings."}, {"term": "What is Proofreading?", "definition": "Thoroughly reviewing and editing your email for errors, including misspellings, grammar, and punctuation mistakes."}, {"term": "Why be Concise?", "definition": "Keeping emails short and to the point for efficient and effective communication, while avoiding excessive wordiness."}, {"term": "What is meant by Keeping Calm?", "definition": "Avoid sending emails in anger or when emotionally charged; instead, address the issue in person or over the phone to prevent unnecessary conflicts."}]}

Children + Distractions:
Using distraction to encourage positive behaviour
Distraction means shifting your child’s attention away from something that’s frustrating or boring to something more engaging or interesting.
You can use distraction when children are likely to behave in challenging ways. For example, this might be when they:
	are getting cranky
	have been sitting still for a long time
	are having trouble sharing or taking turns with others.
Pointing out something interesting, starting a simple game, pulling funny faces – you’ve probably come up with many tricks like these to distract your child.
Distraction usually works. So it’s a great option for encouraging positive behaviour in many situations.

Tips for distracting children and encouraging positive behaviour
Here are distraction tips that usually work for children of all ages:
	Tune in to your child’s behaviour, and try distracting your child when you first notice them getting frustrated, bored or cranky.
	Give your child something else to do. Introduce a new activity, toy or game, or show your child something new they can do with the toy they already have.
	Change the scene. Put your child where they can see different things, or move your child to a new spot either inside or outside.
	Think ahead. Have a few ideas for fun activities. It could be as simple as planning some outside play when you can see that your child is getting bored inside.
	Sing some songs or rhymes together. This can be useful when you can’t stop what you’re doing, like when you’re driving or cooking.
	If you’re out and about, take some toys or books that you can pull out when you need them.

For older children, you can try these ideas as well as the tips above:
	Change the topic of conversation.
	Suggest a simple game or activity. For example, suggest your child tries a jigsaw or a game of Uno if they say they have nothing to do.
	Suggest a break when things aren’t going well. For example, you could say, ‘Looks like you’re feeling frustrated with your drawing. What about riding your scooter instead?’
	Suggest your child does something they usually enjoy, like reading their favourite book or listening to some music.

If you sense that your child is bored and needs distraction, why not encourage your child to come up with their own ideas? Making the most of boredom can be great for your child’s creativity and problem-solving skills.

When not to use distraction to change children’s behaviour
Distraction works best when you can see that your child is about to get upset or behave in a challenging way.
Distraction won’t help if your child:
	has hurt someone
	is having a tantrum
	is very upset.

In situations like these, it’s best to deal with the behaviour directly.
For example, if your child has hurt another child, it might be tempting to distract both children with toys or activities. But this doesn’t help your child understand that it isn’t OK to hurt other people. It might be better to use quiet time or time-out, if your child is old enough to understand these consequences.
Also, trying to distract your child when they’re having a tantrum might send the message that your child’s strong feelings aren’t important. Instead you can use time in to help toddlers calm down or our steps for helping older children calm down.

Flashcards:
{"term": "What is Distraction in Behavior Management?", "definition": "A strategy involving shifting a child's attention away from frustrating or challenging situations to more engaging or interesting activities to encourage positive behavior."}
{"term": "What are good Situations for Using Distraction?", "definition": "Appropriate times to use distraction, such as when a child is getting cranky, has been sitting still for a long time, or is having trouble sharing or taking turns with others."}
{"term": "What are some Distraction Tips for Encouraging Positive Behavior?", "definition": "Useful strategies for distracting children, including introducing new activities, changing the environment, planning fun activities, singing songs, bringing toys or books, and encouraging creativity when boredom strikes."}
{"term": "When Not to Use Distraction?", "definition": "Instances where distraction may not be effective or appropriate, such as when a child has hurt someone, is having a tantrum, or is very upset, and alternative approaches like addressing the behavior directly or using quiet time or time-out are more suitable."}
{"term": "What is a Distraction Strategy?", "definition": "A technique that shifts a child's attention from frustrating or boring situations to more engaging or interesting activities to encourage positive behavior."}
{"term": "What are Effective Distraction Situations?", "definition": "Appropriate times to use distraction, including when a child is becoming irritable, has been sedentary for an extended period, or is struggling with sharing or taking turns with others."}
{"term": "What are some Distraction Tips for Children?", "definition": "Useful strategies for distracting children, such as introducing new activities, altering the environment, planning enjoyable activities, singing songs, bringing toys or books, and promoting creativity during moments of boredom."}
{"term": "What are some Inappropriate Distraction Scenarios?", "definition": "Instances where distraction may not be a suitable approach, like when a child has caused harm to someone, is experiencing a tantrum, or is highly upset, and alternative methods such as addressing the behavior directly or implementing quiet time or time-out are more suitable."}

{"flashcards": [{"term": "What is Distraction in Behavior Management?", "definition": "A strategy involving shifting a child's attention away from frustrating or challenging situations to more engaging or interesting activities to encourage positive behavior."}, {"term": "What are good Situations for Using Distraction?", "definition": "Appropriate times to use distraction, such as when a child is getting cranky, has been sitting still for a long time, or is having trouble sharing or taking turns with others."}, {"term": "What are some Distraction Tips for Encouraging Positive Behavior?", "definition": "Useful strategies for distracting children, including introducing new activities, changing the environment, planning fun activities, singing songs, bringing toys or books, and encouraging creativity when boredom strikes."}, {"term": "When Not to Use Distraction?", "definition": "Instances where distraction may not be effective or appropriate, such as when a child has hurt someone, is having a tantrum, or is very upset, and alternative approaches like addressing the behavior directly or using quiet time or time-out are more suitable."}]}
Given a block of text, extract key terms and their explanations, and format them into a set of flashcards in JSON format. Each flashcard contains a term and its corresponding definition.

{"flashcards": [{"term": "Define Model Penal Code (MPC)", "definition": "A model code created by the American Law Institute in 1962, serving as a template for state criminal codes and leading to significant criminal law reforms in various states."}, {"term": "What are General Principles of Liability?", "definition": "Part I of the MPC, which outlines fundamental concepts of criminal liability."}, {"term": "What are Definitions of Specific Offenses?", "definition": "Part II of the MPC, which provides detailed definitions of specific criminal offenses."}, {"term": "What are Treatment and Correction Provisions?", "definition": "Part III of the MPC, covering aspects related to the treatment and correction of offenders."}, {"term": "What is the Organization of Corrections Departments?", "definition": "Part IV of the MPC, dealing with the structure and organization of corrections departments and divisions."}, {"term": "What is an Elements Analysis?", "definition": "A method used by the MPC to break down crimes into their essential elements necessary for establishing liability."}, {"term": "Define Mens Rea", "definition": "The mental state of a defendant, which the MPC standardized in its definitions of offenses, helping to determine culpability."}]}
